images.tombstone: Robert Frederick Blum (American, 1857–1903) Spanish Courtyard, 1883 Oil on canvas Cincinnati Art Museum, Gift of Joni Herschede and Museum Purchase with funds from the Fanny Bryce Lehmer Endowment
images.description:
Many of the houses are built in the Moorish style, round patios, or courts, cooled by fountains, and open to the sky; and as the inhabitants pass much of their time in these courts, and on the terraced roofs, during the summer season, it follows that many a glance at their domestic life may be obtained by an aerial spectator like myself, who can look down on them from the clouds.

Geoffrey Crayon [Washington Irving], Tales of the Alhambra, 1832

images.tombstone:
Robert Frederick Blum (American, 1857–1903)
Toledo Water-Carrier, 1882
Oil on panel
Baker/Pisano Collection
images.description: Courtyards, gardens, and patios, as well as their entryways, were popular subjects for American artists visiting Spain.

images.tombstone:
William Merritt Chase (American, 1849–1916)
Sunny Spain, 1882
Oil on canvas
Collection of Lois and Arthur Stainman
images.description:
Mr. Chase shows a Scene Near Madrid and Sunny Spain. The former is rich in tone, full of warm, subdued color, giving the effect of sunlight delicately, without glare. If [it has] any fault at all, it is too dry and too juiceless. . . . [Sunny Spain] seems to be a study of the deadening, drying, sapping effect of sunlight in tropical climes, reached without the cheap effect of dazzling highlights or bottomless-pit shadows. The effect of heat; stagnating, absorbing heat, as well as light, are rendered. Textures of roof and wall and sand are well given. 

“Art Loan Exhibition,” Indianapolis Journal, November 7, 1883

images.tombstone:
William Merritt Chase (American, 1849–1916)
Outskirts of Madrid, 1882
Oil on canvas
Yale University Art Gallery, Gift of Duncan Phillips, B.A.
images.description: This painting features fewer conventional Spanish themes than Chase’s Sunny Spain, and the factory smokestack in the background speaks to increasing modernization and its problems.

images.tombstone:
Robert Frederick Blum (American, 1857–1903)
Toledo Water-Carrier, 1882
Oil on panel
Baker/Pisano Collection
images.description: Mules and muleteers were popular subjects among artists from the United States and feature prominently in their Spanish landscapes, reinforcing the country’s reputation for preindustrial labor.

images.tombstone:
Samuel Colman (American, 1832–1920)
Washing Day, Granada, ca. 1872
Oil on canvas, tacked over panel
Private collection
images.description:
Mr. Samuel Colman, our most picturesque landscape painter, whose greatest successes have been in painting the splendors of a time and country not his own, offers us one of his most important pictures. The beauty and the merits of this work are obvious. Its faults escape us because Mr. Colman first pleases us in general effects, next interests us with the materials of his work. We look at this landscape, we see the glare and feel the heat of the afternoon sun; we almost, in fancy, mingle with the crowds below the castle’s towering walls and delight in the dusty splendors of days filled with the glory of the Spaniard and the Moor.

“Art: Exhibition of the National Academy of Design,” The Round Table: A Saturday Review of Politics, Finance, Literature, Society and Art, May 7, 1864

images.tombstone:
John Frederick Lewis (English, 1804–1876) 
Part of the Alhambra from the Alameda del Darro, from Lewis’s Sketches and Drawings of the Alhambra, made during a Residence in Granada in the years 1833–34, 1835
Lithograph
Victoria and Albert Museum
images.description: Images that featured Granada’s ancient bridges, arches, and buildings along the Darro River were popular subjects for artists of the time, as seen in Coleman’s painting and Lewis’s print.

images.tombstone: Current view of a section of the Darro
images.description: The location of Coleman’s scene, the embankment of the Darro River, is now unrecognizable. Already in Coleman’s time, work on a new street, the Calle de Reyes Católicos, had begun to encase the river. The close proximity of the river and the buildings was a trademark of Granada’s early architecture.

images.tombstone:
Mariano Fortuny (Spanish, 1838–1874)
The Slaughter of the Abencerrajes, 1870
Oil on canvas
Museu Nacional d’Art de Catalunya, purchased 1949
images.description:
On the opposite side of the Court of Lions, is the Hall of the Abencerrages [sic]; so called from the gallant cavaliers of that illustrious line who were here perfidiously massacred. There are some who doubt the whole truth of this story; but our humble attendant, Mateo, pointed out the very wicket of the portal through which they are said to have been introduced, one by one; and the white marble fountain in the centre of the hall, where they were beheaded.

Geoffrey Crayon [Washington Irving], Tales of the Alhambra, 1832

images.tombstone:
Jean Laurent (French/Spanish, 1816–1886)
Granada–Temple of the Patio of Lions (Alhambra), 1860–86
Photo on collodion glass
Fototeca del Patrimonio Histórico, Ministerio de Educación, Cultura y Deporte, Madrid
images.description: Nineteenth-century artists often used Laurent’s photographs of the Alhambra for inspiration or verification of the building’s architectural details for their paintings.

images.tombstone:
Camino (Spanish, died 1888) 
Granada, Courtyard of the Lions (Alhambra), ca. 1880 
Albumen print from wet collodion negative 
Chrysler Museum of Art, Museum purchase
images.description: The location of Fortuny’s scene, the Hall of the Abencerrajes, is right off the Patio de los Leones. Photographs often capture the patio from this hall.

images.tombstone:
Jean Laurent (French/Spanish, 1816–1886)
Granada–Alhambra. The Hall of the Abencerrajes, 1863–1880
Collodion glass plate stereoscopic negative
Fototeca del Patrimonio Histórico, Ministerio de Educación, Cultura y Deporte, Madrid
images.description: Stereoscopic photographs such as this offered an immersive experience of the legendary location that Fortuny had populated with members of the Abencerrajes family.

images.tombstone:
Walter Gay (American, 1856–1937)
Cigarette Girls, Seville, 1895
Oil on canvas
Colby College Museum of Art, Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Bronson Griscom
images.description:
We were taken to the work-rooms where the leaves are rolled into cigars. As soon as we were taken in the room, we were assailed by a hurricane of noise: they were all talking, singing, and quarreling at the same time. I have never heard such an uproar. They were for the most part young, and some of them were very pretty. The extreme negligence of their dress enabled one to appreciate their charms in full liberty.

“Great Tobacco Factory of Spain,” Flag of Our Union, vol. 22, June 1867

images.tombstone:
Walter Gay (American, 1856–1937)
Las Cigarerras, 1894
Oil on canvas
Goya Museum, Castres, France, Musée d'Orsay
images.description: As the first establishment of its kind in Europe, the Royal Tobacco Factory in Seville was a major tourist attraction during the nineteenth century. Its popularity among travelers was not unrelated to the fact that it mainly employed women.

images.tombstone:
Gustave Doré (French, 1832–1883)
Cigarerras at Work in the Fabrica de Tabacos of Seville, from Jean-Charles Davillier, Spain: Social Life and Customs
London: Bickers and Son, 1881
Wood engraving
From the American Geographical Society Library, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries
images.description: Doré’s image of Seville’s Royal Tobacco Factory shows the dual exploitation of women as mothers and workers. This socially progressive idea was absent from the usual exoticising representations of the cigarreras.

images.tombstone:
Jean Laurent (French/Spanish, 1816–1886)
Sevilla–La cigarrera (natural), 1860–1886
Glass plate negative
Fototeca del Patrimonio Histórico, Ministerio de Educación, Cultura y Deporte, Madrid
images.description: The cigarreras of Seville (women workers in the Royal Tobacco Factory) rose to literary fame following the publication of Prosper Merimée’s novella Carmen in 1847 and achieved even greater heights with Georges Bizet’s 1875 opera of the same name. Laurent’s photo from his series “Real Types” casts an actual cigarrera as a stage character.

properties.name: Away from the tourist gaze (Dénia and Ronda)

images.tombstone:
Childe Hassam (American, 1859–1935)
Church Procession, Spain, ca. 1883
Oil on canvas
Private collection
images.description:
[Our ship] stopped at some of the Spanish ports. . . . to take on freight. So that we would sometimes stay for several days or a week at some of the ports. In that way we went through the Alhambra. . . . I made some watercolors there in the Alhambra. 

Childe Hassam interview with DeWitt Lockman, 1927, quoted in Childe Hassam: American Impressionist, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2004 |
We walked from Grandia to Denia; the Mediterranean on our left, blue and calm as a lake, and on our right a country rich in the relics of antiquity. Denia takes its name from a temple consecrated to the Great Diana of Ephesus. We noticed on our way a ruined tower, bearing the name of Sertorius.

From Denie to Alcoy the country is extremely fertile, appearing indeed to be one immense orchard, with palms here and there, rearing their graceful heads high above the orange and pomegranate trees. The gathering of the carobs was just over, and one saw garlands suspended over the white walls of cottages, which lighted by an African sun, shone with great brilliancy through the rich masses of foliage.

Baron Ch. Davillier, Spain: Social Life and Customs, translated by J. Thomson, 1876

images.tombstone:
António Passaporte (Portuguese,1901–1983)
Dénia, the Pier and the Castle, ca. 1927–36
Photograph
Fototeca del Patrimonio Histórico, Ministerio de Educación, Cultura y Deporte, Madrid
images.description: In Hassam’s time, in the late 1800s, the steep esplanade of the Dénia Castle was used as a terraced vineyard. In 1920, the terrains were divided into twenty lots and sold to different owners. This later photograph features in the background the giant figure of Christ that was erected in 1927 and destroyed in 1938.

images.tombstone:
Childe Hassam (American, 1859–1935)
Plaza de la Merced, Ronda, 1910
Oil on panel
Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection, 
on loan at the Museo Nacional Thyssen-Bornemisza, Madrid
images.description: Hassam’s painting of Ronda demonstrates his continuing quest for locations and scenes hidden from the eyes of a usual tourist. Just as Church Procession, Spain, this painting shows that the artist was more interested in light, color, and movement than in the people.

images.tombstone:
Ernest Lawson (American, 1873–1939)
Segovia, ca. 1916
Oil on canvas
Minneapolis Institute of Arts, The John R. Van Derlip Fund
images.description:
I am glad you like the Spanish monastery picture as it seemed to me that I got some of the austere quality of Spain in it. Spain is not all gaiety and sunshine, and especially in the centre part has a character of ruggedness and gloom part of the time.
 
Ernest Lawson letter to Sallie Casey Thayer, April 26, 1921, in Charles C. Eldredge, “Ernest Lawson’s Spain,” American Art, 2003

images.tombstone:
Jean Laurent (French/Spanish, 1816–1886) and His Studio
Seville–View of the Alcázar and the Cathedral of Toledo from Fuencisla, ca. 1870
Glass plate negative
Fototeca del Patrimonio Histórico, Ministerio de Educación, Cultura y Deporte, Madrid
images.description: The similarities between Laurent’s and Lawson’s landscapes are as striking as their differences: the two artists used the same point of view, but, in his painting, Lawson changed the scale, making the cathedral belltower seem much higher. The Alcázar, still in ruins at the time of the photograph, was restored in the early twentieth century.

images.tombstone:
Robert Henri (American, 1865–1929)
Segovia, Spain, 1906
Oil on panel
Courtesy of Stephen and Miriam Seidel
images.description: Henri visited Segovia in 1906. His painting offers a less detailed and more impressionistic view of the town and cathedral than the landscapes by Laurent and Lawson.

images.tombstone:
Carrie Hill (American, 1875–1957)
View of Segovia, ca. 1925
Oil on canvas
Birmingham Museum of Art; Promised gift of Dr. Julius E. Linn, Jr.
images.description: Hill’s version of Segovia appears even more distorted than Lawson’s, bringing to mind Spanish old master El Greco’s attenuated and colorful views of Toledo.

images.tombstone:
Jean Laurent (French/Spanish, 1816–1886)
Segovia–382. General Visit of the Roman Aqueduct, ca. 1870
Albumen print on original mount
Chrysler Museum of Art, Museum purchase, in memory of Alice R. and Sol B. Frank
images.description: Laurent’s photograph of Segovia’s famous Roman aqueduct presents a different, albeit equally popular, tourist attraction to the city.

images.tombstone: Current view of Segovia from the Alcázar
images.description: This photograph of Segovia is a current view of the city from the perspective of the Alcázar.

images.tombstone:
David Roberts (Scottish, 1796–1864)
The Fortress of the Alhambra, Granada, 1836
Oil on canvas
Harvard Art Museums/Fogg Museum, Gift of Richard L. Feigen
images.description:
The fact is, that nothing is known of Spain; those who could have appreciated the richness of its architecture have generally gone to Italy or Greece. My portfolio is getting rich, the subjects are not only good, but of a very novel character. I begin to doubt whether I shall be able to paint half of them, they already amount to nearly 100, and I have yet six towns to visit, from which I expect many fine subjects. 

Letter dated January 30, 1833 |
Granada is the most beautiful situation that can be imagined. It lies at the foot of a ridge of high mountains, called the Sierra Nevada, or Mountain of Snow. So great is their height that even in the intense heat of summer they are covered in snow. In front of the city stretches an immense plain called the Vega, at least 20 miles in length, highly cultivated, and, although it is still winter with you at home, here the spring is far advanced. So hot is the sun during the day that I cannot stand to sketch for ten minutes together, but am obliged to cross into the shade. On a hill immediately above Granada rises the old Moorish palace of the Alhambra, a great part of which is in the most perfect preservation. Courts, halls, terraces, galleries, and fountains out of number are here, and golden fish still disport themselves in the numerous ponds. The gardens are filled with orange and lemon trees laden with fruit, and even at this early season the flowers are in full bloom and beauty. 

Letter dated February 13, 1833
 
Both published in: James Ballantine, The Life of David Roberts, R.A.: Compiled from His Journals and Other Sources, 1866

images.tombstone: Current view of the Alhambra and Generalife
images.description: Roberts’s improbably high point of view of the Alhambra, from the roof of an imaginary building close to the hilltop plaza Mirador de San Nicolás, allowed him to capture more of the complex than can actually be seen from any one location.

images.tombstone:
Felix Octavius Carr Darley (American, 1822–1883)
Frontispiece, The Alhambra, from Washington Irving’s The Alhambra, 1851, rev. ed. 
New York: G. P. Putnam
Lithograph
Chrysler Museum of Art, Jean Outland Chrysler Library
images.description: Darley’s view of the Comares Tower from below is one of the most iconic, published, and reproduced. It appears in any number of portfolios and travel guides through the nineteenth century.

images.tombstone:
Mary Bradish Titcomb (American, 1858–1927) 
The Alhambra, ca. 1906 
Oil on canvas
Chrysler Museum of Art, Museum purchase with funds given in memory of Joan Foy French by her daughters Wendy and Christina
images.description: The Comares Tower, also prominent in Roberts’s panorama, was among the most popular sites of the Alhambra. Artists had a convenient point of view from the Darro River to capture the sight.

images.tombstone: Current view of the Tower of Comares
images.description: It was a challenge for artists to find a viewpoint of the Alhambra that allowed them to capture the entire complex. The closest location was beneath a steep hill, which dwarfed the grand structure, making it look less imposing.

images.tombstone:
John Singer Sargent (American, 1856–1925)
Ilex Wood, Majorca, 1908
Oil on canvas
Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection, on loan at the Museo Nacional Thyssen-Bornemisza, Madrid
images.description:
The ascent on leaving Malaga is very long and beautiful, by a zigzag road, cut over the mountains, through banks of cactus (which is planted for the fruit), aloes, vines, and fig-trees, olive woods, orange gardens, cypresses, and other trees. The views on the ascent into the interminable mountains of the interior are exquisite, as well as those commanding the town and sea. We reached the Venta de los Najos just at dusk, having walked down a long and steep descent from the ilex wood; indeed, my companions walked a great part of today’s journey.
 
Elizabeth Mary Leveson-Gower Grosvenor Westminster, Narrative of a Yacht Voyage in the Mediterranean during the Years 1840–41, 1842

images.tombstone:
John Singer Sargent (American, 1856–1925)
Moorish Courtyard, 1913
Oil on canvas
Myron Kunin Collection of American Art, Minneapolis, MN
images.description:
The Albayzín (Albaicín), a still more populous district, served at one time as a refuge to the Moors of Baeza, when their town fell into the hands of the Christians. This suburb, built on a hill in front of the Alhambra, is the quarter of Granada which still preserves its ancient aspect, as much on account of its population as on account of the few Moorish buildings that escaped the general destruction of the old town. One of the most remarkable of these is the Casa del Chapiz, on the hill of the same name. It is entered through a small court, where we noticed a window divided by a slender column, from which there is a view of the hill of the Alhambra. This building still preserves traces of ancient Moorish decoration in marble, stucco, and curious carvings in wood.


Baron Ch. Davillier, Spain: Social Life and Customs, translated by J. Thomson, 1876

images.tombstone:
Jean Laurent (French/Spanish, 1816–1886)
Patio of a Moorish House in the Albaicín, ca. 1860
Albumen print
Victoria and Albert Museum
images.description: Like many nineteenth-century artists, Laurent focused on the dilapidated, multifamily nature of the once grand Casa del Chapiz.

images.tombstone:
Treviño and Arroyo (Firm active ca. 1900)
Casa del Chápiz, 1910
Photograph, old positive
Museo Sorolla
images.description: This photograph shows a more intimate and detailed view of the Casa del Chapiz in Granada's Albaicín quarter.

images.tombstone:
Joaquín Sorolla y Bastida (Spanish, 1863–1923)
Street in Granada, ca. 1909
Oil on canvas
Museo Sorolla
images.description:
We turned up the alley, passed from it into another, and from that into a third, always ascending, without seeing anything extraordinary, although I looked curiously in every direction. Narrow streets, squalid old houses, old women dozing on the doorsteps, mothers carefully inspecting their children’s heads, gaping dogs, crowing cocks, ragged boys running and shouting, and the other things that one always sees in the suburbs; but in those streets nothing more. But gradually, as we ascended, the appearance of the houses and the people began to change; the roofs became lower, the windows fewer, the doors smaller, and the people more ragged. In the middle of every street ran a little stream in a walled gutter in the Moorish style; here and there over the doors and around the windows one saw the remains of arabesques and fragments of columns, and in the corners of the squares fountains and well-curbs of the time of the Moorish dominion. At every hundred steps it seemed as if we had gone back fifty years toward the age of the caliphs. 

Edmondo De Amicis, Spain and the Spaniards, 1895

images.tombstone:
Francis Frith (English, 1822–1898) 
Gipsy Town. Granada, ca. 1871 
Whole-plate albumen print from wet collodion glass negative
Victoria and Albert Museum
images.description: Frith’s photograph shows the Albaicín, the historically Islamic and Romani neighborhood of narrow, winding streets and white carmens, homes surrounded by high walls. Sorolla’s painting Calle de Granada is a more intimate view of the neighborhood and pictures the entrance to the Realejo, Granada’s Jewish quarter.

images.tombstone: Current view of the Albaicín from the Alhambra
images.description: This contemporary view, seen from the edge of the Alhambra Palace with its fortress wall visible at the right, shows the density of the homes and narrow winding streets of Albaicín neighborhood below.

images.tombstone:
Joaquín Sorolla y Bastida (Spanish, 1863–1923)
Hall of the Ambassadors, Alhambra, Granada, 1909
Oil on canvas
The J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles
images.description:
From this court they passed to the great Hall of the Ambassadors, which occupies the centre of the Tower of Comares, and is the most imposing single apartment of the palace. It was the Sultan's audience-chamber, and was well calculated to impress the visitor with his magnificence. Its lofty dome, seventy-five feet in height, like the palace of King Solomon, is "ceiled in cedar and painted with vermilion."

Lizzie W. Champney, Three Vassar Girls Abroad, 1883.

images.tombstone:
Francis Frith (English, 1822–1898) 
The Ambassadors’ Court. Granada, ca. 1871 
Whole-plate albumen print from wet collodion glass negative
Victoria and Albert Museum
images.description: Frith’s photograph—and Sorolla’s painting—shows one of the most popular, and oft-depicted, views of Granada: the Comares Tower’s Ambassadors’ Court in the Alhambra.

images.tombstone:
Mary Bradish Titcomb (American, 1858–1927) 
The Alhambra, ca. 1906 
Oil on canvas
Chrysler Museum of Art, Museum purchase with funds given in memory of Joan Foy French by her daughters Wendy and Christina
images.description:
North of Granada rises a long ridge of rocky land between two rivers, the Darro and Xenil; the ridge slopes downwards towards the town, intersected by a long avenue of elm-trees, but spreading out near the top into two tablelands, or broad terraces, bordered by steep ravines. On the western terrace stands the Alhambra, its base washed by the Darro. On the eastern one stand the Vermilion Towers, beyond which the land slopes more gently down into the precincts of the town of Granada. These two terraces were formerly girt with walls and towers and connected together with winding lanes; and within the circuit thus fortified, stood the palaces and villas of the Caliphs of Granada, as well as their chief fortresses; so many that the enclosure was called a city.

Susan Hale, A Family Flight Through Spain, 1883

images.tombstone:
David Roberts (Scottish, 1796–1864)
Tower of Comares, from Thomas Roscoe's The Tourist in Spain, Granada, 1835
London: Robert Jennings and Co.
Engraving
Chrysler Museum of Art, Jean Outland Chrysler Library
images.description: The view that Roberts’s print of the Alhambra’s Comares Tower provides here—seen from the Darro River below—is a fantasy and required great artistic license.

images.tombstone:
Felix Octavius Carr Darley (American, 1822–1883)
Frontispiece, The Alhambra, from Washington Irving’s The Alhambra, 1851, rev. ed. 
New York: G. P. Putnam
Lithograph
Chrysler Museum of Art, Jean Outland Chrysler Library
images.description: Darley never traveled to Spain, and his lithograph of the Alhambra’s Comares Tower is strikingly similar to Roberts’s. He likely referenced the Scottish artist’s print when making his own.

images.tombstone: Current view towards the Alhambra, Torre de la Comares
images.description: This contemporary photograph highlights the difficulty in capturing the Comares Tower from the perspective seen in many paintings and prints of the building.

images.tombstone:
Joseph Pennell (American, 1860–1926)
The Generalife, Granada, 1894
Pen and ink on paper
Milwaukee Art Museum, gift of The Art Institute of Chicago
images.description: Pennell’s drawing is from the same perspective as many artistic views of the Alhambra’s Comares Tower, but it shows the Generalife, the summer palace of the Alhambra’s Nasrid rulers.

images.tombstone:
Edwin Lord Weeks (American, 1838–1920)
Interior of a Mosque at Cordova, ca. 1880
Oil on canvas
The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore, Maryland
images.description:
It is impossible to describe the impression one feels on entering the mosque of Cordova for the first time; the numerous columns which support the vault cross each other like forest trees and form long perspectives, which continually change as one penetrates farther into the interior. A half-obscurity, reigning here, as indeed in all Spanish churches, adds another charm to the poetry of these alleys of marble. The columns now number eight hundred and sixty, but were much more numerous formerly: it is said that there were as many as twelve hundred.

Baron Ch. Davillier, Spain: Social Life and Customs, translated by J. Thomson, 1876

images.tombstone:
Jean Laurent (French/Spanish, 1816–1886)
Interior View of the Mosque or Cathedral, Córdoba, 1875
Albumen silver print 
The J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles
images.description: Laurent’s photograph of the interior of the Mosque or Cathedral at Córdoba highlights the famed columns receding into the distance, a favorite view of nineteenth-century artists.

images.tombstone:
John Frederick Lewis (English, 1804–1876) 
The Mosque at Cordova, from Lewis’s Sketches and Drawings of the Alhambra, made during a Residence in Granada in the years 1833–34, 1835
Lithograph
Victoria and Albert Museum
images.description: Like Laurent and his photograph, Lewis underscored the mosque’s cavernous interior and multiple arches and columns. His view also introduces a Catholic ritual, as the building was used as a church at the time.
